runs.text: Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is fiction. It has animal characters who talk and behave like people.
Have students point to the characters in the illustration.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
something is to carefully watch it.
a small bug climbing up the wall.
Which tools can you use to
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word that identifies the animals in the story. (mice)
What does the young mouse observe about the moon? Find the sentence that answers the question.
The young mice want to fly to the moon and bring back cheese for their friends. What does this tell you about them?
If you had the chance to fly to the moon, would you go? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that dawn is another word for sunrise, and dusk is another word for sunset.
Point out that the text has labeled pictures that show information about coyotes. Explain that the author imagines what the coyotes might say if they could talk and shows it in the speech bubbles.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
is a chance for something good to happen.
to try out for the soccer team.
When did you last have an
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the times of day when coyotes are most active. (sunrise, sunset)
When do coyote pups have the opportunity to leave their den? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How do mother and father coyotes help to raise their pups? Explain.
Have you ever seen a coyote? What was it doing? If not, then what wild animals have you seen in your area?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students read the sentences to a partner. Then have them switch roles.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (period), 2 (question mark), and 9 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement). Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title. Explain that this is a comic. Students should pay careful attention to both the illustrations and the words in the speech bubbles.
For the first reading, read the girls dialogue while students read the boys dialogue. Then pair students to reread the comic. Partners can switch roles during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all words with long
spellings in the comic and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of each students errors on their Student Observation Form.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about different sea animals that make their own light. Point out that each label names the animal shown in the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Flowers use their scent, or smell, to
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word that tells what part of an anglerfish attracts other fish. (light)
How does the vampire squid protect itself? Find the sentences that answer this question.
Why is it important for these animals to make their own light? Explain.
Which of these animals do you find the most interesting? Why?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with long i.
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts. For example, as you read sentence 8, pause briefly after
Point out that each group of words relates to one idea in the sentence. Have children echo your phrasing.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a functional text about ocean zones.
The author includes a paragraph about each zone at the top. The diagram below shows how deep each zone is and which animals live there.
Remind students that in order to understand the text, they must think carefully about how the words and pictures connect.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the eBook for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a boy who finds a surprising sight.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
a kite flying over the park.
What is something you would like to
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find how many mice live under the floor. (five)
What does Kyle witness in the kitchen? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why are the mice frightened? Explain.
What would you do if you saw mice ice skating in your freezer? Would you react the same way that Kyle did?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a story about insects that speak and act like humans. Have students point to the main characters in the illustration.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
troll tricked the man into giving up his gold.
Which characters from books, movies, or TV shows would you describe as
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word in the story that tells when Spider spins her web. (night)
Why does Firefly think that Spiders actions are unfair? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How are Firefly and Spider alike? How are they different?
Do you think Spider will change her devious ways? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
